title: Causes and Symptoms of Chronic Pelvic Pain
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Many conditions can cause chronic pelvic pain . All can have similar symptoms, and that often makes it hard to figure out the source of the pain. The main symptom is pain that lasts for more than 6 months, but there are usually other symptoms as well. Understanding your symptoms can help you and your doctor begin to pinpoint the cause or causes of your chronic pelvic pain. Here are some of the causes and the related symptoms:

content_blocks.text: Many conditions can cause chronic pelvic pain . All can have similar symptoms, and that often makes it hard to figure out the source of the pain. The main symptom is pain that lasts for more than 6 months, but there are usually other symptoms as well. Understanding your symptoms can help you and your doctor begin to pinpoint the cause or causes of your chronic pelvic pain. Here are some of the causes and the related symptoms:

sections.heading: Endometriosis
content: In endometriosis, cells that normally line the inside of the uterus (the endometrium) grow outside on organs such as the ovaries, bladder , or rectum.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Pelvic pain or cramps before or during your period

content_blocks.text: In endometriosis, cells that normally line the inside of the uterus (the endometrium) grow outside on organs such as the ovaries, bladder , or rectum.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Pelvic pain or cramps before or during your period

sections.heading: Adenomyosis
content: This condition is similar to endometriosis . Cells that normally line your uterus (the endometrium) invade the muscle tissue of the uterus wall (the myometrium). Many women with adenomyosis don't have any symptoms.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Feeling of pressure on your bladder or rectum
Periods that last longer than usual

content_blocks.text: This condition is similar to endometriosis . Cells that normally line your uterus (the endometrium) invade the muscle tissue of the uterus wall (the myometrium). Many women with adenomyosis don't have any symptoms.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Feeling of pressure on your bladder or rectum
Periods that last longer than usual

sections.heading: Interstitial Cystitis
content: Women with interstitial cystitis have an inflamed bladder. The inflammation is not caused by an infection. This condition tends to affect women in their 30s and 40s.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: You need to urinate very often
Often feeling an urgent need to urinate

content_blocks.text: Women with interstitial cystitis have an inflamed bladder. The inflammation is not caused by an infection. This condition tends to affect women in their 30s and 40s.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: You need to urinate very often
Often feeling an urgent need to urinate

sections.heading: Urinary Tract Infection
content: Bacteria are usually the cause of urinary tract infections . Infections can involve any part of the urinary tract, including the kidneys , bladder, and urethra. Urinary tract infections are much more common in women than in men.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Feeling pressure in your lower pelvis
Pain or a burning sensation when you urinate
Often feeling an urgent need to urinate
Needing to get up at night to urinate
Urine has strong or bad smell
Only a trickle of urine comes out

content_blocks.text: Bacteria are usually the cause of urinary tract infections . Infections can involve any part of the urinary tract, including the kidneys , bladder, and urethra. Urinary tract infections are much more common in women than in men.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Feeling pressure in your lower pelvis
Pain or a burning sensation when you urinate
Often feeling an urgent need to urinate
Needing to get up at night to urinate
Urine has strong or bad smell
Only a trickle of urine comes out

Understanding your symptoms can help you and your doctor begin to pinpoint the cause or causes of your chronic pelvic pain. Here are some of the causes and the related symptoms:

sections.heading: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
content: This is an infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, or ovaries that causes them to become inflamed and infected. Most often, it is a sexually transmitted bacterial infection , like gonorrhea or chlamydia . These bacteria enter the uterus through the vagina and leave the fallopian tubes to infect surrounding organs like the ovaries. Scars left by the infection may cause chronic pelvic pain, but more commonly, the pain is acute.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Vaginal discharge having an unusual color, texture, or odor
Abdominal or pelvic pain in a specific area or more widespread
Menstrual cramps that are worse than usual
It hurts when you press on certain areas of your pelvis

content_blocks.text: This is an infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, or ovaries that causes them to become inflamed and infected. Most often, it is a sexually transmitted bacterial infection , like gonorrhea or chlamydia . These bacteria enter the uterus through the vagina and leave the fallopian tubes to infect surrounding organs like the ovaries. Scars left by the infection may cause chronic pelvic pain, but more commonly, the pain is acute.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Vaginal discharge having an unusual color, texture, or odor
Abdominal or pelvic pain in a specific area or more widespread
Menstrual cramps that are worse than usual
It hurts when you press on certain areas of your pelvis

sections.heading: Pelvic Congestion Syndrome
content: Pelvic congestion is just like the varicose veins that some women have in their legs, but it affects the veins of the pelvis. Blood backs up in the veins, making them become enlarged and engorged. Pelvic congestion causes chronic pelvic pain in some women.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Pain starts 7-10 days before your period
Pelvic pain is worse when you sit or stand

content_blocks.text: Pelvic congestion is just like the varicose veins that some women have in their legs, but it affects the veins of the pelvis. Blood backs up in the veins, making them become enlarged and engorged. Pelvic congestion causes chronic pelvic pain in some women.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Pain starts 7-10 days before your period
Pelvic pain is worse when you sit or stand

sections.heading: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
content: Chronic pelvic pain sometimes isn't only due to problems with reproductive organs or the urinary tract; other organs in the pelvic area, if "diseased," can present as pelvic pain. Irritable bowel syndrome, an intestinal condition that often causes pain, may be the cause.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Pain relieved by a bowel movement

content_blocks.text: Chronic pelvic pain sometimes isn't only due to problems with reproductive organs or the urinary tract; other organs in the pelvic area, if "diseased," can present as pelvic pain. Irritable bowel syndrome, an intestinal condition that often causes pain, may be the cause.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Pain relieved by a bowel movement

sections.heading: Uterine Fibroids
content: Fibroids are noncancerous tumors that grow in, and on, the wall of the uterus. Not all women who have them notice symptoms, but for some, fibroids can be painful.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Feeling pressure or fullness in your abdomen
Pain or cramps during your period

content_blocks.text: Fibroids are noncancerous tumors that grow in, and on, the wall of the uterus. Not all women who have them notice symptoms, but for some, fibroids can be painful.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Feeling pressure or fullness in your abdomen
Pain or cramps during your period

sections.heading: Levator Syndrome
content: Sometimes, spasms of a pelvic muscle called the "levator ani" cause pelvic pain.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Pain doesn't seem to be related to bowel movements.
You wake up at night in pain.
Pain usually lasts less than 20 minutes at a time.

Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Pain doesn't seem to be related to bowel movements.

sections.heading: Pelvic Support Problems
content: Sometimes women have pelvic pain when the muscles and ligaments that hold organs in place weaken. This causes organs like the uterus, the bladder, or the rectum to move from their normal places and herniate into the vagina . The vagina may also change shape. Pregnancy and giving birth may cause these kinds of problems.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Feeling like something is falling out of your vagina
Pelvic organs bulge into the vagina, or even stick out the vaginal opening, in severe cases

content_blocks.text: Sometimes women have pelvic pain when the muscles and ligaments that hold organs in place weaken. This causes organs like the uterus, the bladder, or the rectum to move from their normal places and herniate into the vagina . The vagina may also change shape. Pregnancy and giving birth may cause these kinds of problems.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Feeling like something is falling out of your vagina
Pelvic organs bulge into the vagina, or even stick out the vaginal opening, in severe cases

sections.heading: Vulvodynia
content: Vulvodynia is pain that affects the vulva for no apparent reason. The pain of vulvodynia may be constant or it may come and go.
Symptoms you may have:
bullets: Burning or stinging sensations in the vulva
Pain when something presses on the vulva, like during sex or when you straddle a seat

content_blocks.text: Vulvodynia is pain that affects the vulva for no apparent reason. The pain of vulvodynia may be constant or it may come and go.
Symptoms you may have:
associated_bullets: Burning or stinging sensations in the vulva
Pain when something presses on the vulva, like during sex or when you straddle a seat

sections.heading: Psychological Causes
content: For some women, the root of pelvic pain is psychological. That's not to say that the pain isn't real. There just isn't an identifiable physical cause. Some people have emotional problems that only show up as physical symptoms. Women who have suffered sexual abuse or assault often have chronic pelvic pain afterward.
Symptoms you may have:

content_blocks.text: For some women, the root of pelvic pain is psychological. That's not to say that the pain isn't real. There just isn't an identifiable physical cause. Some people have emotional problems that only show up as physical symptoms. Women who have suffered sexual abuse or assault often have chronic pelvic pain afterward.
Symptoms you may have:

sections.heading: Other Causes
content: Less common causes of pelvic pain include:
Ovarian remnant. Sometimes, when you have surgery to remove your ovaries, a small part of an ovary is left behind. If this happens, the leftover piece can get cysts that can be painful.

Cervical cancer. Continuous pelvic pain is a sign of cervical cancer. You could feel it near your appendix if the cancer is advanced. If the discomfort is due to cancer, it'll usually come with other symptoms like:
Ovarian cancer. Pelvic pain can be one of many signs of ovarian cancer. If yours is, what you feel can be persistent and severe. It might come with:
bullets: Abnormal vaginal bleeding, like bleeding between periods, heavy bleeding during your period, or bleeding after sex
Urinary issues like always feeling like you need to pee or having to pee often

sections.heading: Vaginal cancer.
content: One symptom is pelvic pain. Others include:
Endometrial cancer. Pain in your pelvis is a sign of late-stage endometrial cancer. You might also have:
Radiation treatment. Radiation treatment for cancer can damage healthy cells and tissue. That damage can lead to scar tissue that can bring pain.
bullets: A lump of mass in your vagina
Unusual bleeding or discharge in your vagina

content_blocks.text: One symptom is pelvic pain. Others include:
associated_bullets: A lump of mass in your vagina

content_blocks.text: Endometrial cancer. Pain in your pelvis is a sign of late-stage endometrial cancer. You might also have:
associated_bullets: Unusual bleeding or discharge in your vagina

content_blocks.text: Radiation treatment. Radiation treatment for cancer can damage healthy cells and tissue. That damage can lead to scar tissue that can bring pain.

meta_description: WebMD explains the symptoms of chronic pelvic pain, including the various conditions that may cause it.
